author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route focuses on fundamental upward movement. Encourage her to look for the next handhold before moving, and to use her legs to push up, rather than pulling with her arms. The holds are large and easy to grip, building confidence.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This line teaches basic side-to-side movement. Guide her to match hands on the larger hold mid-way, and to shift her hips over her feet to stay balanced as she moves sideways. It's a great introduction to traversing.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: Focus on teaching her to shift her body weight from one foot to the other. Before each hand move, she should make sure her weight is securely on the opposite foot, making it feel easier to reach the next hold.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route encourages lifting the feet high. Coach her to trust her feet on small-looking but positive holds and to drive up powerfully with her legs. This builds leg strength and flexibility.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: Designed to practice reaching moves. The holds are good, but slightly farther apart. Remind her to straighten her arms, turn her hip into the wall, and reach with her whole body, not just her arm.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route introduces the concept of a mantle, or 'press-up' move. On the large green hold, she'll need to press down with her hands to bring her feet up, similar to getting out of a swimming pool. It's a key skill for topping out.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: The diagonal nature of this route is perfect for practicing 'flagging'â€”using one leg as a counterbalance. Encourage her to swing her free leg out to the side to prevent her body from swinging away from the wall (barn-dooring).

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route teaches the 'twist-lock' or 'drop-knee' technique. To make the reach to the next hold, guide her to turn her hip towards the wall and drop the same-side knee down. This brings her center of gravity closer to the wall and extends her reach.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route introduces underclings. Coach her to get her feet high and her body low to use the undercling hold effectively. The goal is to pull outwards and upwards on the hold, creating tension that keeps her on the wall.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route focuses on using sidepulls. Teach her to maintain tension by leaning away from the hold, creating an opposing force. Body position is key; she needs to keep her center of gravity low and to the side.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: Here we introduce the 'gaston' move, which feels like prying open an elevator door. She will use a side-facing hold with her thumb down, pushing away from it. This move relies on shoulder strength and body tension.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route encourages a more dynamic style. The holds are spaced to promote a small, controlled jump or 'pop'. Coach her to bend her knees and explode upwards, coordinating the push from her legs with the pull from her arms.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: A great route for developing pinch strength. The holds require squeezing with the thumb against the fingers. Remind her to wrap her thumb as much as possible and engage her core to stop from swinging out.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This one is all about slopers. Teach her to find the best part of the hold, keep her body weight directly underneath it, and maintain a bent arm to maximize friction. It's more about body position than pure finger strength.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: An introduction to the heel hook. The large blue hold is perfect for this. Guide her to place her heel on the hold and pull with her leg. This will help her take weight off her arms and easily reach the next hold.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route features pockets. Teach her to use her strongest fingers (usually middle and ring) and to pull straight down. It's important to build finger strength gradually and listen to her body to avoid injury.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: This route introduces small but positive crimps. Encourage an 'open-hand' grip rather than a 'full crimp' (thumb over index finger) to build strength safely. The focus is on precise footwork and body tension to make the holds feel bigger.

author: Gemini 2.5 Pro
beta: A challenging traverse on the steeper wall that requires constant body tension. Coach her to keep her core tight and her feet pressed into the wall. This prevents her feet from cutting loose on the overhang.
